content: The Act may be cited as the "Stop Errors in Credit Use and Reporting Act" or the "SECURE Act." Legal recourse for consumers is provided. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to allow courts to award injunctive relief for non-compliance with consumer protection requirements. Injunctive relief can include costs and attorney fees for the prevailing party. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to allow courts to award injunctive relief for non-compliance with consumer protection requirements, including costs and attorney fees for the prevailing party. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to include negligent, willful, or knowing violations in consumer protection requirements. SEC. 3. INCREASED REQUIREMENTS FOR CONSUMER REPORTING AGENCIES AND FURNISHERS OF INFORMATION. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to include provisions for documentation provided by consumers, enhancing requirements for consumer reporting agencies and furnishers of information. The Bureau will provide reports on disputes received by reporting agencies and prescribe rules for gathering dispute information. Consumer reporting agencies must issue a proposed rule to assure maximum accuracy of consumer reports. The rule may consider matching first and last names to improve report accuracy. This includes disclosing the address, telephone number, and permissible purpose of the person obtaining the consumer report, as well as providing the consumer with a credit score. Notification requirements for adverse information are also updated, including free disclosure after notice of adverse action or offer of credit on materially less favorable terms. The Fair Credit Reporting Act requires consumer reporting agencies to provide free disclosures to consumers upon receiving notifications under specific sections, or from affiliated debt collection agencies. During a transition period, agencies must provide current credit reports and other required disclosures without charge until final rules are established by the Bureau. The Errors in Credit Use and Reporting Act amends section 615(a) to direct consumer reporting agencies to provide consumers with disclosures when taking adverse actions based on consumer reports. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to ensure consumers receive a free copy of their consumer report and notification in cases of less favorable terms. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to include provisions for notifying consumers about their consumer report and directing consumer reporting agencies to provide disclosures to consumers. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to include a Bureau rule defining certain disclosure requirements, with considerations on enabling consumers to determine reasons for adverse actions taken against them. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to include a Bureau rule defining disclosure requirements to determine reasons for adverse actions taken against consumers and protect consumer privacy. Additionally, regulatory reform is addressed in Section 4. Section 621 of the Federal Credit Reporting Act is amended to establish 3 publicly available registries of consumer reporting agencies, including nationwide consumer reporting agencies, nationwide specialty consumer reporting agencies, and other consumer reporting agencies. All consumer reporting agencies are required to register. All consumer reporting agencies defined in section 603(f) must register with one of the registries established by the Bureau within a specified timeframe. SEC. 5. STUDY OF A PUBLIC CREDIT REPORTING SYSTEM. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study on international credit systems, accuracy of existing consumer credit reporting systems, feasibility of a national government-administered system, consumer benefits, and costs. Findings will be published within 18 months. The Comptroller General of the United States will publish findings on international credit systems and consumer credit reporting within 18 months of the Act's enactment. SEC. 6. EFFECTIVE DATE: The provisions of this Act and its amendments will take effect 6 months after enactment.
